 A. BACKGROUND Health status, health system and financing prior to the war. 1. By the end of the 1980s, the contrast between the development of health care services and the uneven achievements in health status suggested that systemic problems were limiting further progress in health outcomes in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BH)1. Like most other formerly socialist economies in Central and Eastern Europe, BH had a well developed health system. The whole population enjoyed reasonable access to a large network of clinics, hospitals and public health facilities. There were 5.8 hospital beds per 1,000 population and 2.6 doctors per 1,000 population.2 There were 46,000 health workers, of whom about 65% were professionally qualified. On the one hand, the system had achieved remarkable coverage and the use of high technology; on the other hand, some key health status indicators still showed low achievements. 2. Although substantial gains were achieved in health outcomes during the two decades preceding the war, the indicators of health status showed a mixed picture. The infant mortality rate had declined from 56 per 1,000 live births in 1970 to 21 per 1,000 live births in 1991. But, partially due to the weak primary care network, the percentage of infants immunized against childhood illnesses in 1991 was less than in other European socialist countries, with the exception of the former USSR. While the age- standardized mortality rate for communicable diseases, maternal and perinatal causes (87 per 100,000 population) was worse than the average of 52 per 100,000 for other European socialist countries, the life expectancy of 73 years at birth was at the higher end of the range observed in the region. 3. The pre-war health system suffered from a number of problems. A supply-dominated approach to centralized planning had led to the proliferation of large hospitals and heavy reliance on specialized poly-clinics, with relatively little attention being given to primary health care or family practice. The centralized decision-making process did not encourage strategic planning to achieve the most efficient use of resources. Instead, decisions were most often the result of bureaucratic bargaining, rather than a rational assessment of needs and available resources. Clinical decisions were not based on considerations of the effectiveness or costs of the desired interventions. 4. Total health expenditure was around 6.5 percent of GDP, leading to an annual health expenditure per capita of about $150 in 1991, which was on the high side of the range encountered in the region. In addition to the large infrastructure, the reasons for these high costs were that payments were based on norms for number of beds, items of equipment, as well as staff and size of buildings, all of which combined to create perverse incentives. Over-specialization and high rates of utilization, referrals and prescribing also contributed to high costs. 5. As part of the wider Yugoslav system, a health insurance system operated through a parastatal fund which had limited autonomy. It essentially funded activities carried out by the existing public services. Funds for health care were raised through a compulsory payroll-based scheme with contributions from employer and employee, passed through the health insurance fund in Sarajevo. A plan to deal with the increasing imbalance between health sector costs and revenue was initiated shortly before the war. It called for strengthening the role of the health insurance fund as an independent purchaser, encouraging private provision of health services, ensuring that the expenditure of the insurance fund did not exceed its income, and increasing co- payments. The implementation of this plan was prevented by the war. Impact of The War on Health Status and the Health Care System 6. The war has taken an enormous toll on the health status of the population. The drastic reduction of access to priority health services at the primary and secondary levels, decline in living conditions, malnutrition and intense psychological stress have caused dramatic declines in overall health status of the population. Based on information from Sarajevo, the infant mortality rate is estimated to have doubled, reaching an average of 30 to 40 per 1,000 live births in urban areas. The incidence of serious congenital malformations rose from 0.7% to 2.1% of births during the war. Almost 25% of these malformations were anencephalus (absence of a brain) or hydrocephalus (excessive water in the brain), which will have been detected during the pre-natal period and managed appropriately, had access to and functions of diagnostic and treatment services not been severely constrained during the war. Similarly, premature births have doubled, while the average birth weight has dropped by more than 20 percent. The rate of perinatal mortality rose from about 15.3 per 1,000 live births before the war to 38.6 per thousand during the conflict. Available data on morbidity show a two- to five-fold increase in the number of people affected by epidemics and communicable diseases (influenza, tuberculosis, hemorrhagic fever), with a surge in the number of fatal cases. Although reliable figures are scant, the MOH in each entity reports an increasing trend in infant and matemal mortality, tuberculosis, mental disorders and suicides, accidents and mortalities due to chronic diseases. 7. In the area of reproductive health3, family planning as reflected by contraceptive use had never been given a high priority within the health care system of formner Yugoslavia. As a result, the incidence of induced abortion was traditionally high. With the onset of the war, the number of induced abortions increased significantly. Pre- and intra-war data for Sarajevo indicate that abortions increased from a ratio of one for every birth to at least two for every birth. The high rate of abortions, especially under constrained medical resources, including the capacity to sterilize equipment, creates the condition for subsequent low-grade infections and infertility. With the end of the conflict, particular attention will need to be given to primary prevention of unwanted pregnancies with contraceptives, as opposed to the dependency on abortion as a secondary prevention technique, as well to infertility counseling and clinical services.  -3- Hospital Infrastructure 8. The hospital infrastructure has suffered major damage as a result of the war. The direct (damage or destruction due to shelling) and indirect (absence of maintenance and repair due to lack of resources) effects of the war have led to a collapse or loss of function of a significant portion of the hospitals. The deterioration and destruction of physical facilities have constrained the availability of good quality physical space for the provision of essential hospital services. Some equipment cannot be used due to disrupted electrical systems. In some hospitals, uncompleted structures are deteriorating due to prolonged exposure to the elements. 9. In the Federation, the destruction of hospital buildings has led to the elimination of about 35% of beds and the loss of function of many others. About 7,700 hospital beds remain "active" throughout the Federation (3 beds per 1,000 population). The Federation MOH plans to develop a streamlined and efficient hospital system, based on a network of eight cantonal hospitals and the three Clinical Centers in Mostar, Sarajevo and Tuzla. A summary of the methods used for the assessment of hospital infrastructure is presented below. Detailed estimates are shown in Appendix 1. 10. Program preparation and appraisal were based on several documents and the outputs of the Working Group of the Federation MOH. A War Damage Assessment was prepared with the assistance of the International Management Group (IMG) in April, 1996. The process involved five teams of BH nationals. Each team included an architect, a civil engineer, a plumbing and sewage specialist, a mechanical engineer and an electrical engineer. This assessment was a useful source of data for the appraisal. The War Damage Assessment report was further modified by the Working Group of the Federation MOH to include various "projects" that the Working Group found judicious, many of which were parts of a long term program interrupted by the war. It was necessary to identify more clearly the objectives and nature of the various projects in order to justify selections on the basis of explicit and rational criteria. The criteria for inclusion in the Federation Program were the following: * Relation to war: In addition to repairing direct and indirect war damage, the completion of work interrupted by war and new construction considered critical were eligible for inclusion in the broad Program. * Essential care: Program should focus on essential care, avoiding unnecessary hi-tech equipment. The facilities should ensure hygienic conditions of care for patients and efficient conditions of work for doctors, nurses and para-medical professionals. * Geographical distribution: The number of functioning beds after completion of civil works should be approximately uniform across the Federation and less than or equal to 4 beds per 1000 inhabitants. About 10% of the beds should be used for tertiary care. * Time: Projects should be implementable within a short period, say 2 or 3 years at most. * Effectiveness: Civil works should enable buildings to be effective (i. e., to function and enable workers to deliver care) immediately after completion. * Funding: Beyond the criteria specified, no arbitrary limit was fixed for the Federation MOH Program. It was clear that the Government and donors had limited resources, hence decisions were based on criteria of need, relevance to efficient service delivery and prospects for sustainability. Clinical Skills and Quality of Care 17. Basic education and in-service training were disrupted by the war. Established curricula could not be adhered to, on account of damage to infrastructure, insecurity, loss of faculty and the absence of required textbooks and supplies. In-service training and continuing education were severely constrained, as the emphasis was on responding to the immediate needs imposed by war-time casualties, and there was very limited access to professional joumals. Doctors and nurses have not maintained knowledge of the use of modern, cost-effective medical technology. 18. The combination of inadequate equipment, loss of some of the most capable professionals and a weakened educational system has resulted in decreased clinical skills and quality of care in the hospitals. There is a clear need to ensure that the care provided in hospitals is consistent with modem and safe practices by restoring and improving upon in-service training for doctors, nurses and laboratory technologists, and by providing adequate equipment, joumals and books for self-instruction. 19. Improving the quality of care is important both in practical terms and conceptually. Although only a limited study of health status and health outcomes in BH was conducted in the preparation of this Project, emphasis was placed on two other dimensions of quality: structures and processes. "Structure" refers to the buildings and equipment discussed earlier. The underlying assumption is that without proper settings and functioning equipment, good medical care cannot occur. From the earlier presentation of civil works and equipment requirements, it is evident that additional resources are required to provide adequate buildings and equipment for appropriate care in BH. "Process" considers not only that medical technology exists, but also whether what is known to be scientifically sound health care is applied, such as appropriate clinical history, physical examinations, diagnostic tests, justification of diagnosis and therapy. The assumption is that without proper procedures, good health outcomes cannot be obtained. Clearly, the process of care in BH needs to be improved to guarantee care of good quality to the population. Health Care Financing 20. The unified financing system collapsed during the war. Three "systems" emerged, two for the Federation and a separate one for RS. As for the current Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Bosnian-majority areas, the insurance fund merged with the Ministry of Health in January 1994. In the HVO Army-controlled area, a separate insurance fund has been in operation since 1993. 21. In the Federation, knowledge about the current sources of financing for the health sector is very patchy. Non-payment of salaries, donations in kind and amassed debts mean that the health system has been and remains demonetized to a large extent. There are at least seven major sources of financing for health services in the Federation: * budget payments from the Federal Ministry of Finance for nine (later 10) institutions in the former BH Army-controlled areas; * funds (magnitude unknown and unestimated) originating in, or channeled through, cantons and municipalities;
 * the health insurance fund in HVO Army-controlled areas; * unestimated private out-of-pocket fee-for-service payments for both public and private care; * international assistance through multilateral and bilateral agencies and NGOs (unestimated); * debts (total debts are estimated to be over $200 million); and * military funds for war hospitals and clinics (unestimated). 22. There are substantial differences in resource availability between the areas controlled by the BH Army and the territory controlled by the HVO Army. Using tentative data for December 1995, expenditure in the HVO army controlled areas is almost twice that of the BH Army controlled area (6.2 DM per capita per month compared with 3.2 DM per capita per month). Salaries are low throughout the Federation, but were almost three times higher in the HVO army controlled areas (614 DM per health worker per month on average) compared to the BH army controlled areas (215 DM) in December 1995. In March 1996, salaries for health sector workers in the areas formerly controlled by the BH Arrny were increased to 520 DM per month, but counterparts have advised that these increases have not been fully sustained since March. 23. In Republika Srpska, the main institution for health care financing is the Public Health Fund, which is engaged in the collection and distribution of capital through regional funds that in turn undertake direct payment to health institutions for services at prices set by the Public Health Fund. These prices are not based on actual cost and payments to health institutions, and therefore, they do not cover even the minimum needs of the health system. Salaries declined drastically during the war -- a doctor received, and still receives, about DM 75 per month. Other health workers receive about DM 45 per month. Money for the Public Fund comes from compulsory contributions of 14 percent of employees' salaries, paid by employers. In addition, the government assumes responsibility for the unmet financial needs of the Public Fund, a responsibility that could not be met during the war. 24 . Health insurance contributions covered only 20 percent of costs between 1991 and 1996, whereas all citizens had access to the services in principle. About 2 to 3 percent of the total income of health institutions came from user charges, while 30 to 40 percent of health institutions' expenditures were covered by humanitarian assistance (drugs and supplies, food, etc.). The RS MOH plans major changes in the health financing system, including the introduction of voluntary health insurance in addition to the existing compulsory health insurance. In this planned system, groups of beneficiaries of free health services will be restricted to pregnant women, mothers of infants, persons aged less than 15 years or over 70 years, those suffering from infectious diseases or mental illnesses, patients requiring renal dialysis, and others yet to be specified. The government will be responsible for these groups and for those unable to contribute to either health insurance fund.
 - 10 - B. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY: FROM EMERGENCY TO DEVELOPMENT 25. With the end of the war, the health sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina faces a triple challenge. It must: continue to function on an emergency basis for some time; undertake its recovery; and transition to a modem efficient system. First, and for some time to come, the sector professionals will continue to live and work under emergency-type conditions. With living conditions still precarious, controllable epidemics will continue to break out, and health services will still handle larger proportions of emergency cases and war-related injuries than their colleagues in the average country. Second, the reconstruction must start without delay. Especially in light of severe resource constraints, this puts an enormous pressure on sector authorities to prioritize activities and to plan large investments quickly, in many cases without access to all relevant information. Such plans will have to be guided by the judicious use of the most reasonable estimates of resource availability and prospects for sustainability. Third, and highly critical, the reconstruction effort must avoid rebuilding the unwieldy pre-war health system. This requires that much attention be given to the right balance between modem primary health care services and high quality but streamlined hospital services. Developing a medium term strategy 26. The Federation: Initiating its response to the above-mentioned challenges, with the assistance of WHO/EURO, the Federation MOH has outlined the guiding principles for the development of a national master plan for the country's health sector recovery4. This document covers both the short-term reconstruction needs and the future structure and functions of the health sector that could be achieved in the medium-term. Five pillars were identified in the master plan: (i) health system design (sector profile, health financing, administrative and organizational structures); (ii) human resources development; (iii) development of the infrastructure and basic essentials (physical reconstruction, medical equipment and supplies, pharmaceuticals, information systems); (iv) public health programs (communicable diseases and epidemics, non-communicable diseases, nutrition and health promotion, maternal and child health/ family planning, environmental health); and (v) rehabilitation (physical and psycho-social/mental). These pillars also constitute the framework for the Task Forces that the Federation MOH has established or intends to establish for specifying the reconstruction and reform master plan. 27. The Republika Srpska: With the assistance of WHO/EURO, the RS MOH has prepared its Strategy of Health Development for Republika Srpska by the Year 2000, which outlines the guiding principles for the development of the health system5. This document covers both the short-to-medium term goals and the means to achieve the goals in broad terms. As a part of the comprehensive Program for the hospital sector, which was prepared within the overall post-war health system reconstruction and development program of the Government, the Project will contribute to the successful reconstruction and reform of the health sector by (a) restoring basic hospital services, and (b) establishing a sustainable health system through carefully planned health finance reforms. This section presents: (a) the policy context; (b) an overview of the cost attached to alternative approaches to the proposed strategy for recovery in the hospital sub-sector; and (c) the estimated contribution of this Project to the health status of the population. 122. The policy environment and linkage to economic and sector work. The Project is consistent with the focus of the post-war recovery in Bosnia and Herzegovina and with the Health Program of the Ministry of Health in each entity. The country faces three major challenges. First, the reconstruction and recovery program necessitated by the war damage has to be implemented. Second, new governance structures and institutions for economic management must be established. Finally, the transition to a market economy must be managed successfully.7 The Project fits into this policy environment in two ways. First, it will result in a net inflow of resources into the health sector. The broader Essential Hospital Services Program provides the donor community with a framework for investment to support the recovery of the health sector. For example, the Governments of Canada, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, as well as the United States Agency for International Development, have expressed interests in the sub-sector. Second, the Project will facilitate the development of management structures and systems to ensure effective risk pooling, improved efficiency and cost control . 123. No formal sector work was done prior to the appraisal of this Project, due to the severity and urgency of post-war needs, the rapid pace of work in BH and the very limited availability of organised databases. Instead, for each of the main components of the Project -- rehabilitation/ renovation, medical equipment and health finance reforms -- the Working Group of each MOH, the International Management Group (IMG), Bank staff and consultants conducted the minimum necessary analyses to make informed judgements about investment priorities. These analyses of limited scope were done with a focus on: (a) the needs expressed by the Ministry of Health of each entity; (b) prospects for sustainability, based upon projected rates of economic growth and expected levels of expenditure in the health sector; (c) the minimum level of investments to ensure that secondary-level hospital services of good quality will be available to support the functions of a reformed primary health care/ sub-hospital level; and d) the need to avoid uncoordinated large-scale investments in the hospital sub-sector, thereby avoiding a situation whereby future recurrent costs will starve the sub-hospital level of needed resources. It is most likely that, considering the current climate of donor fund shortages, without the explicit priorities set forth in the Program and the proposed Project, donors would focus on high-visibility tertiary-level equipment and civil works, to the detriment of much needed investments in cantonal hospitals. The second scenario would have consisted of a "wholesale" reconstruction of the hospital sub- sector, without introducing the basis for ensuring minimal sustainability. In the Federation, for example, this approach would have resulted in the restoration of the pre-war hospital bed capacity of 10,296, whereas the entire Program plans to restore a capacity of 8,476, a reduction of almost 20 percent. The Project, by comparison, will impact on only 50 percent of this reduced number. This wholesale reconstruction alternative, together with the rehabilitation of facilities, would have also restored all the inefficiencies of the pre-war system: poorly maintained structures and insufficient recurrent operational funds to ensure that the hospital system functions adequately. Although difficult to quantify, the proposed Project strongly reduces the risks of reconstructing highly under-financed hospital services in the near future. 126. Direct Economic Benefits: The project investments in the hospital sector will restore to fully functional status a restricted number of beds in secondary hospital facilities and will support them with carefully chosen equipment (see Appendices on Hospital Equipment and Supplies for methodological details). The chosen process was designed to include only equipment that (a) has been demonstrated to be both clinically effective and cost-effective and (b) in total, will generate recurrent financial costs that could be sustained within the projected financial capacity of the hospital 127. This Project supports an overall strategy to bring about more cost-effective use of resources committed to the health sector. The benefits of reallocating resources to more effective uses can take two forms. One is lower costs to achieve the same impact that current health services have on health outcomes and health status. The other form is a heightened impact on health outcomes and health status for the same level of resource use. In practice, the benefits of health reform are likely to take both forms. 128. However, many of the Project's benefits -- particularly those associated with health-sector reform -- cannot be accurately quantified. Nevertheless, their potential order of magnitude is substantial, as two indicative calculations suggest. First, the health sector is likely to absorb at least 4 percent of GDP in the medium term. If health reform increases the efficiency with which the sector uses resources by even 5 percent, this will translate into a stream of productivity gains equivalent to 0.2 percent of GDP per year. 129. Indirect Economic Benefits: Over and above these direct economic benefits, there are indirect benefits. When health systems succeed in keeping people healthier or deliver more effective curative care, the population can lead more productive lives. Workers produce more because they spend less time recuperating from their own illnesses or caring for family members who are sick; students learn more;
 - 40 - and some people avoid the enduring ill-effects that certain illnesses bring. In short, human capital is preserved and quality of life is enhanced. 130. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, a functioning, reforming health sector that is sustainable should also bring other intangible but important benefits. The strategy for nation-building and for promoting lasting peace rests on recreating viable, valued systems for meeting people's basic needs. Access to effective health services is a high priority in this context -- a credible peace dividend. 131. Improvement of Health Status. This risk will be mitigated by the establishment of a Project Implementation Unit in each entity, that will build on the resources and experience of the PIU which has been developed and is operational for the War Victims Rehabilitation Project in the Federation. Each PIU will be supported by appropriate technical assistance and by the Bank's Social Sector Operations Officer, based in Sarajevo. Project implementation could also be delayed through shortages of co-financing. This risk is being mitigated by active communication among the Ministry of Health in each entity, the Bank and likely donors. 134. Significant risks within the Project, for the most part, are associated with: (i) political context of and constraints on the definition of health sector policy; (ii) financial constraints on Project size, including limited availability of IDA funds and co-financing; (iii) current state of post-war disruption and evolving reconciliation within the country; and (iv) pressures for early action to improve health service delivery within BH, which may not consider the most effective and sustainable approaches to restructuring the health sector. 135. One major set of risks is associated with the Federation Government's present commitment to a policy of making cantonal governments responsible for most aspects of health policy, financing and administration, possibly within a matter of months. Several factors underlie that commitment: (i) the tradition of substantially decentralized health care within the former Yugoslavia; (ii) consistent with the rationale for decentralization, the desire to locate responsibility for health services as close as possible to the people affected by them; and (iii) the political impetus to avoid creating health insurance arrangements that effectively cross-subsidize health care provision among high- and low-income areas. Making cantons responsible for health care financing and delivery will remove from the Federation's political stage this politically intractable issue of equity in access to health services. Potentially, the Federation Government's commitment to this governance strategy for the health sector could result in up to ten separate health care financing and delivery systems with the Federation, in addition to the centralized system in RS. In practice however, this risk is somewhat mitigated by the fact that the legislation under preparation opens the possibility for cantons to choose to group together and develop coordinated or integrated financing systems. The end result will therefore likely be the emergence of two to four separate health financing systems. These groupings will correspond to a considerable degree to prior patterns of affiliation among cantons, a translation of the current political reality in BH. 136. Other risks, also linked to the Federation Government's commitment to this strategy, could result in less than optimal implementation of the Federation MOH reform process. These are: (i) the difficulty or inability of the poorest cantons to finance their obligation to provide access to a Federation- specified minimum package of care; (ii) the limited capacity of the Federation MOH to exert sufficient policy leverage to maintain control over the restructuring of health care delivery and financing systems within the various cantons; (iii) the limited capacity of the Federation MOH to turn its health reform strategy into an implementable process; (iv) the high administrative cost of managing and operating multiple cantonal health care financing and delivery systems for a small population. These costs may prove unsustainable in a recovering economy and a still relatively poor country. Counterpart policy makers expect that cantonally based health care systems will provide unequal access to care across cantons, reflecting the different average levels of income across cantons.

First, the pre-war Yugoslav health system was among the most sophisticated in Eastern Europe, and it retains health sector personnel with the vision, the will and the skills to achieve sustainable transformation of the current war-damaged system. In that context and with judicious use of technical assistance, there is a real possibility that demonstration of the economies of scale that could be achieved in a simplified, less fragmented system will lead to revision of the Federation strategy. Second, the task of reforming health care delivery and financing has proven to be highly complex in all other transition economies -- and even in established market economies -- which did not face the complex context of post-war BH. Expectations must therefore be kept at reasonable levels, with considerable emphasis on productive partnerships among BH, IDA and the donors. Third, the Project itself is intended to provide a broad range of technical assistance that should enhance and build up the Federation's and Republika Srpska's capacity to design, implement and sustain systemic reforms.

 Appendix 2 Page 1 of 6 Bosnia and Herzegovina Essential Hospital Services Project (The Federation) Medical Equipment and Supplies Component Background Biomedical technology represents a fundamental component of the health care delivery process, on which the most of diagnostic, therapeutic and rehabilitation procedures are based. Both in industrialized and developing countries, health services in hospitals are largely based on the use of technology. As reported in the scientific literature, a close relationship can be found between the per- capita GNP and the value of installed medical equipment. In particular, data collected at international level -- on a large number of industrialized and developing countries -- show an almost constant ratio between these three components: - per-capita GNP - per-capita health care expenditure - per-bed equipment value An immediate explanation can be found for justifying these data: medical technology is expensive in terms of investment but also in terms of running costs. Therefore, if immediate problems related to investments can sometimes be solved by external aid (for countries with insufficient internal resources for investments), in the medium- to long-term the running costs must be sustained with internal resources. As a result, even in the case of large donations of new and advanced technology (as it happened in many developing countries), a mechanism of automatic readjustment takes place in a short period of time, whereby only that portion of the externally-funded investment that is sustainable within local resources is maintained and able to survive. The main reasons for the premature de-commissioning of unsustainable technology can be found in the costs for consumable materials and for maintenance that, on average, represent a yearly charge of 30- 35% of the cost of installed equipment. Unfortunately, running costs incidence is particularly noticeable in the two fundamental technological components of diagnostic services: radiology and clinical laboratory, which together represent around 50% of the installed equipment in a medium-sized hospital. Medical technology for the other diagnostic and therapeutic services must cover the remaining 50%. Any attempt to change this ratio (i.e.: trying to reduce consumable costs) will generate an unbalanced system unable to support the hospital activity adequately. Appraisal of the sustainable level of technology An approxinate quantification of the optimal level of medical technology, in terms of correct ratio between acceptable level of health services and sustainable costs, can be done on the basis of the assumptions reported in Table 1, resulting from analyses carried out in some European countries (M. of Health - Italy 1994; MDIS Reports - U.K. 1992).

 Appendix 7 Page 1 of 11 Bosnia and Herzegovina Essential Hospital Services Project (Republika Srpska) Medical Equipment and Supplies Component Assessment of global program needs Introduction The aim of the exercise was to carry out a rapid and sufficiently detailed appraisal of the status of biomedical equipment installed in hospitals of medium and high complexity (2nd and 3d level health care institutions) to identify the priorities for a medium term program for re-equipping these health institutions. It was organized around the following main activities: * Identification of health institutions * Detailed survey of the status of some of these health institutions * Analysis of data and assessment of priorities for new biomedical instrumentation * Development of a medium-term program to re-equip the priority health care institutions * Quantification of costs for equipment, maintenance and consumables. The present document was prepared on the basis of information collected in the health institutions visited during the mission and of other official documents provided by the Ministry of Health's Working Group of the Republika Srpska. It refers to the global Essential Hospital Services Program in RS, of which the Essential Hospital Services Project in RS is a part. Identification of health institutions In cooperation with the MOH Working Group, nine hospitals and two institutes located in RS were identified as priority second and third-level health institutions which would form the basis for RS's future health care system. The health institutions identified were the following: - Clinical Center - Banja Luka - Institute of Public Health - Banja Luka - General Hospital - Prijedor - General Hospital - Gradiska - General Hospital - Doboj - General Hospital - Bijelina - Hospitals of Pale/Kasindol/Sokolac - General Hospital - Trebinje - General Hospital - Brcko - General Hospital - Zvornik - Institute of Physical Rehabilitation - Banja Luka The first four institutions (Banja Luka Clinical Center, Institute of Public Health, Prijedor Hospital, Gradiska Hospital) were visited, to carry out a detailed inventory --analysis of the status of structures and existing equipment with the MOH Working Group. Data collection General information on the organization and activities of the above four institutions was obtained during preliminary meetings with the Hospital Directors and through a questionnaire sent to the hospitals. In addition, visits to the Departments of Radiology, Clinical Laboratory, Surgery, ICU, Obstetrics & Gynecology and Hemodialysis of each hospital were carried out. The main goal of these visits was to set up an inventory of the most important biomedical equipment installed in the above mentioned departments, assessing the following characteristics for each piece of equipment: - number and type of equipment; - estimated age;
 Appendix 7 Page 2 of 11 Bosnia and Herzegovina Essential Hospital Services Project (Republika Srpska) Medical Equipment and Supplies Component - level of usage; - status (good, medium, poor, very poor, damaged); - maintenance (intemal technicians, manufacturer); - estimated replacement cost of new equipment with similar or better functionality; and - present source of consumables (donation, purchase, not available). During the visits, data were collected for a detailed assessment of the status and consistency of medical equipment installed in the health institutions. It is important to remember that the departments visited hold the largest portion of the total value of medical equipment installed in general hospitals (75- 80%, according to data available from the scientific literature). Table I shows a general summary of the replacement value of equipment in the three hospitals visited by the mission. Table 2 shows some basic health factors (number of beds, population served, number of births per year) and some technology-related indicators (equipment per bed, equipment per inhabitant) for these same three hospitals. From the analysis of the data, it is possible to obtain some useful information for the assessment of priorities and needs of health care structures in terms of technology. The average worth of equipment per bed is around USS5,000, which is about 1/5 to 1/10 of the figure that we can find in Western European countries. However, it should be noted that it is consistent with the pre-war per-capita GDP of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This close relationship between per-capita GNP, per-capita health care expenditure, and per- bed equipment has been demonstrated by a study (D. Bravar et al., IFMBE - CED) carried out at the international level on industrialized and developing countries. Assuming US$5,238 as the average ratio of equipment per bed in the country, the replacement value of equipment in the remaining hospitals of RS has been estimated on the basis of the number of active beds in each hospital. Table 3 shows the global estimate for the nine hospitals. According to the replacement value of equipment, the yearly costs for maintenance, consumables and amortization (assuming a 10-year life span of equipment) have been estimated. These figures are reported in Table 3. A large portion of the equipment found in the hospitals (40%) is considered as obsolete, being older than 15 years (X-ray equipment) or 10 years (other diagnostic and therapeutic equipment). Approximately 1/3 of the remaining equipment, although not obsolete, is not functioning due to the total lack of maintenance during the period of the war. This situation still persists, due to the total absence of MOH resources for systematic maintenance and to the isolation of RS from the other countries of the former Yugoslavia. Determination of priorities for new biomedical equipment On the basis of the data collected during the visits to the hospitals, a first estimate of needs was prepared according to the following criteria: - age and condition of existing biomedical equipment; - hospital size (no. of beds); - catchment area served by the hospital. - pre-war, present and/or foreseen diagnostic and therapeutic activity; and - standardization of essential health services quality between hospitals. In Appendix I ,Table 4, a program for the replacement of obsolete medical equipment is indicated for each hospital. The program is intended as an investment plan to: (i) recover from a long period during the war when no new equipment was purchased; (ii) assure, in the next 4-6 years, a reasonable level of technology on which essential diagnostic and therapeutic services will be based. The aim of the plan is to avoid an increase of the total technology installed in hospitals, which the limited financial resources of the

According to the estimates indicated above, 40% of existing equipment should be replaced, while the remaining 60% should be maintained, with repair of 1/3 of the equipment currently out of use. Estimated costs for equipment maintenance and for consumables for each of the priority hospitals and the Institute of Public Health are reported in Table 4. The availability of local technical resources to provide on-going equipment maintenance would reduce substantially overall maintenance costs from the 9-10% normally charged in manufacturers' service contracts to about 5% of the replacement cost of the equipment. To ensure that local technicians are qualified to provide maintenance services, any provision of equipment will have to include technical training courses, complete servicing technical documentation and an adequate quantity of the most common spare parts. For the purposes of this report, the costs of consumables have been assessed both for the new equipment supported by the program and for the already existing equipment. The criteria used to evaluate the annual estimated expenditure for consumables associated with the equipment are based on the following assumptions: - Radiology equipment: 20% of the replacement cost of equipment - Clinical Laboratory equipment: 95% of the replacement cost of equipment - Other equipment: 5% of the replacement cost of equipment - Hemodialysis equipment: US$30.000/year per dialysis unit (US$60 per treatment x 2 patients/day x 250 days/year) To calculate these percentages, data from national studies (Italian National Research Council - 1986, Italian Ministry of Health - 1994) and from international market analyses (Medical Markets in Western Europe - MDIS Report - U.K. 1992) were used. According to these assumptions and to the average distribution of medical equipment among the different clinical sectors, a global yearly cost of consumables can be reasonably estimated at 25% of the replacement value of the equipment. Conclusions and recommendations In the short period of time available for the mission (one week), it was possible to collect data sufficient only for a rough appraisal of needs in terms of equipment and associated consumables. Nevertheless, during that period, it was possible to gain an overview of the current status of RS hospitals, and to develop a reasonable plan for future medical equipment investments with the aim of providing, for the next few years, the minimal tools necessary to ensure a reasonable level of health services quality to the population. A fundamental step in the implementation of the program will have to involve a precise and detailed assessment of equipment installed in all hospitals in order develop a final updated list of equipment to be provided under the Program, according to the most urgent priorities. The Health Finance Reform Component of the Project is designed to assist the Government of BH, and more specifically the Ministry of Health of each entity (the Federation of BH and the Republika Srpska), in the initial stages of health finance reform. 2. OBJECTIVES 2.1. The broad objective of the Technical Assistance (TA) to be provided by the consultants is to support the development of credible and effective process, delivering specific interim products, in pursuit of: (a) an overall design for a coherent health financing system that would achieve universal access, cost-containment, quality, sustainability, effectiveness and efficiency objectives, and (b) the portability of access to health care between the entities, within the provisions of the constitution of BH. 2.2. More specifically, the objectives of the TA are: 2.2.1. To support the definition of the essential responsibilities of the Federation and the Republika Srpska (RS) in financing a reformed health system, including but not limited to the establishment, within constitutional provisions, of a common approach to issues of access and service delivery, as well as the sets of arrangements for governance, financing and administering the health sector on a sustainable basis. 2.2.2. To support the definition of options for assuring that all citizens in each entity acquire and retain effective access to a minimum package of basic health care services. 2.2.3. To support the identification of a pragmatic, phased and sequenced series of changes for transforming the current health financing regime in each entity into those envisaged for the future, including viable options for promoting convergence toward a common arrangement within constitutional provisions.
 Appendix 12 Page 2 of 5 3. SUMMARY OF REQUIREMENTS 3.1. Consultants are required to assist the Ministry of Health and appropriate institutions in each entity to: (a) identify specific options, and the implications of those options, for introducing a sustainable, efficient, effective and equitable health finance regime; (b) conduct defined studies of limited scope in support of the decision making process in each entity; and (c) develop the capacity of nationals of BH to manage the health sector reform process successfully. 3.2. Assistance is required for a relatively intense start-up phase including policy analysis, relevant surveys of limited scope and training during the first year, followed by on-going support for the initial stage of implementation during the second and third years of the Project. 3.3. Ultimately, policy decisions and strategic choices will be made by the people and constituted authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The technical assistance is explicitly intended to help the nationals and constituted authorities to bring objective criteria and transparent processes to bear upon the decisions and choices. 4. DETAILED SCOPE OF WORK 4.1. Definition of the essential responsibilities of each entity. 4.1. .1. In the Federation, the TA would assist the Federation MOH to specify in more detail the instruments and processes for reintegrating the health finance system, as stated by the Government of BH in the Letter of Development Policy dated May 15, 1996 (Transition Assistance Credit, Report and Recommendation of the President of the International Development Association, Number P-691 1-BIH, August 14, 1996). 4.1.2. In the Republika Srpska, the TA would assist the MOH to specify in more detail the instruments and processes for achieving the broad objectives stated in the "Strategy for Health Development for Republika Srpska by the Year 2000". 4.1.3. The TA would support the exploration and documentation of feasible options for common, or at least compatible, approaches in the two entities, and would facilitate communications according to a schedule to be deternined jointly by the MOH of both entities, but in any case at least monthly. 4.1.4. The TA would include but not be limited to the definition of the appropriate responsibilities and authorities of each MOH, each health insurance fund, cantonal and municipal authorities for policy formulation, financial forecasting, business planning, human resource planning, and related forms of regulatory activity (inicuding regulation of private insurance).
 Appendix 12 Page 3 of 5 4.1.5. Sustainability requires that revenues be sufficient to cover costs in each time period, for the system as a whole and for each component of the system that is expected to be financially sustainable and in financial balance. Analyzing sustainability therefore requires that both resources (and their sources) and costs (and their determinants) be carefully examined. Assessment of the health system's financial sustainability should therefore take into account such factors as revenue bases, efficiency of revenue collection, incentives for providers and consumers to use resources efficiently, linking of decisions on investments in medical equipment and technology to the affordability of their recurrent costs, cost-containment strategies, scale of risk pooling, and exploitation of economies of scale in health delivery and public health systems, revenue collection, information systems, health insurance and provider payment systems, and evaluation systems. 4.1.6. Sustainability analysis should take into account the sensitivity of projections to assumptions made about the future rates and patterns of economic growth within each entity. The results of the sustainability analyses should include the identification of alternative ways of structuring the health sector with the potential to be financially sustainable. 4.2. Assuring Universal Access to Basic Care 4.2.1. The TA will support the identification of options and the implications of those options for: (a) assuring that all people in the Federation and RS acquire and retain access to a minimum package of basic health services and (b) the revenue base that would support this mechanism in the medium term. 4.2.2. Technical work is required in the following areas: (a) identification and costing of options; (b) setting transparent administrative procedures for implementation; (c) identifying priority interventions; (d) indexing for inflation; (e) information needs -- demographic, epidemiologic, service delivery and financial (tax base and health expenditures) and (f) systems for monitoring whether adequate access is in fact universally available. 4.2.3. Transfer of skills to nationals of BH would be crucial to facilitate future iterations of this exercise, as the working of the scheme will change as the economy recovers. 4.3. Phases of implementation during the transition 4.3.1. The TA will support the identification of phased and sequenced series of coordinated changes to transform the current health financing and delivery systems into those envisaged for the future. The developmental tasks to be accomplished during the transitional period should include the following: (i) design of new hospital payment mechanisms and of a strategy for achieving a slimmer, more cost-effective hospital sector;
 Appendix 12 Page 4 of 5 (ii) preliminary design of a restructured primary health care system and of new mechanisms for financing primary care, including the financing links between primary care, outpatient specialist care, and inpatient hospital care; (iii) design of a new and consistent system for monitoring indicators of access to care, quality of health care processes, health status, and health outcomes for each local geographic area; (iv)design of coordinated information and management systems for hospitals, primary care providers, and insurance institutions that in turn would provide a data base for each MOH's functions of research, planning, evaluation, and preparation of inputs to national health expenditure accounts; (v) design of future policies and procedures by which each MOH would regulate cantonal/municipal health systems, including any processes for constraining total health spending within each entity; (vi)defining the basic package of care in terms of either covered health services or threshold levels of average expenditure per person and developing new administrative and financing mechanisms to ensure that low-income cantons/rr.unicipalities can provide universal access to this package of care; (vii) design of management systems, operating systems, and associated computer hardware and software requirements for new insurance arrangements; (viii) design of administrative systems that minimize costs by taking maximum advantage of economies of scale; and (ix)design of systems to address cross-cantonal and inter-entity issues such as referrals and portability of access to health services. 5. DELIVERABLES. The following are key deliverables associated with the TA: 5.1. A documented policy, to be prepared by the Working Group of nationals of each entity, identifying the conceptual, policy and institutional framework for financing the health care system, and defining, within existing constitutional provisions, feasible approaches to promoting consistency of systems between the two entities. The document from each entity should include but not be limited to common themes specified in this paragraph. Approximate due date: Six months from signing of contract. (July, 1997).
 Appendix 12 Page 5 of 5 5.2 Inventories of sources of finance and the areas of expenditure for each entity. Approximate due date: Six months from signing of contract (July, 1997). 5.3. Composition and costs of alternative forms of a basic package of health services. Approximate due date: Nine months from signing of contract (October, 1997). 5.4. At least two nationals of BH in each entity, skilled in specifying and costing alternative forms of a basic health package. Approximate due date: Eleven months from signing of contract (December, 1997) 5.5. At least two nationals of BH in each entity, with demonstrable knowledge of evidence-based health service management, contract setting/monitoring and provider payment alternatives. Approximate due date: Eighteen months from signing of contract (July 1998). 6. REPORTING AND COMMUNICATIONS. The consultants(s) responsible for specific aspects of the TA shall work with and in support of the Ministry of Health of each entity -- specifically, the Working Groups established by each the MOH of each entity and the Essential Hospital Services Project Implementation Unit in each entity. They shall liaise, as necessitated by the stated objectives of the assignment, with other appropriate ministries of each entity and the State Ministry of Finance, the Sectoral Task Force on Health, donor and technical agencies, municipal and cantonal authorities, universities. All reports shall be submitted in hard copy and on disk to the Director of the Project Implementation Unit in each entity. 7. QUALIFICATIONS The consultant(s) shall have: (a) demonstrated competence in supporting health sector reforms, preferably in the transition economies of Central and Eastern Europe; (b) a track record of effectiveness in delivering specified products on schedule; (c) fluency in English language; (d) familiarity with alternative health finance models; and (e) advanced training in the core disciplines of health economics/financing, health planning and epidemiology. Strong skills in oral and written communications and adaptability to rapidly changing contexts are crucial.

doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Essential Hospital Services Project is to support the strategies of the Ministry of Health (MOH) of each entity for the medium term to develop a modern, cost effective and fiscally sustainable hospital network. More specifically, the project will strengthen essential hospital services and establish and support the initial steps in health financing reforms. To accomplish these objectives, the project will support the implementation of the following components: a) physical rehabilitation and reconstruction of essential hospital facilities; b) medical equipment and supplies; c) upgrading of clinical skills and practices; d) health financing reform and implementation support; and e) project implementation support.
